results.title: The Story of Menstruation
results.brief_description: This film was made as an outgrowth of Disney’s contract work with the armed forces during World War II. “The Story of menstruation” was probably the first American educational film with a woman narrator. The first half of the film discusses the natural process of menstruation through colourful yet simple diagrams, whilst the second half gives instruction on coping with behavioural changes and reinforcing gender roles, with a marriage scene followed by a picture of a young woman with her baby, suggesting “the natural course of life”. When this film was screened in schools, girls received a copy of a booklet, “Very Personally Yours”, which pushed Kotex products.

results.title: Catch of the day
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt, Australian Film Commission and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The bright, beautiful and spontaneous ocean is something to wallow in. A young girl plays in the ocean and with the fishes. A dashing surfer rides up on his white steed and declares ‘I’ve come - you’ll never have to chop onions again!’ Jane wakes up from her dream (or was it a nightmare?) Working at the fish market, she endures the sexual innuendo and double entendres from male customers and fellow workers alike. When matters come to a head, she cleverly takes the situation into her own hands and offers a unique solution to unsolicited sexual advances… An impressionistic animation.

results.title: Bare
results.creator_credit: Deborah Strutt, Liz Baulch, Wild Iris Productions and Amanda Roberts
results.brief_description: There are misunderstandings aplenty in this award-winning Australian short when 2 gay boys accidentally catch their lesbian neighbours in an early morning clinch. High density living in all its revealing glory.

results.title: Pierre et Paul = Pierre and Paul
results.creator_credit: Rene Allio, Leon Carre and Yves Robert
results.brief_description:
Pierre, a middle manager in a building company, decides to buy a appartment and live with his girlfriend, Martine. But, the subsequent death of his father and various financial difficulties soon damage his mental equilibrium. When the May ‘68 riots errupt, Pierre goes off the rails.

Credits: Producer, Leon Carre, Yves Robert ; director, Rene Allio ; writer, Rene Allio ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Jacques Dutronc.
Cast: Pierre Mondy, Robert Juillard, Bulle Ogier, Madeleine Barbulee, Helene Vincent.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.

results.title: "War Pictures": Australians at the Cinema 1914-1918
results.brief_description:
A compilation of archival films that chronicles the Australian cinema-going experience during WWI from 1914 to 1918.

Between 1914 and 1918, cinema attendance was on the rise and the local film industry was expanding with over 50 Australian feature films produced during the period. While many of these films have been tragically lost, those that remain offer a rare glimpse into Australian life during this turbulent time.

As the war began, filmmakers rushed to make features about Australia’s involvement. Alfred Rolfe’s ‘Hero of the Dardanelles’ (1915) told the story of Gallipoli, complete with landing scenes shot at Tamarama Beach in Sydney.

However, as the years progressed, war-weary audiences lost their taste for patriotic stories, and a new genre of home-grown comedies emerged featuring knockabout characters from the Australian bush. Throughout the war years, Hollywood dramas, serials, love stories and comedies were also staple attractions, and Charlie Chaplin was an international superstar.

War Pictures offers a wide-ranging selection of local and international material, including a focus on Australia’s ‘lost films’.

Specially commissioned introductions and musical accompaniment offer contemporary audiences a chance to step back time and experience cinema as it was enjoyed during the First World War.

This work was shown at ACMI from 10 March to 26 July 2015 in the ‘War Pictures’ exhibition.

results.title: Three in one
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes and Australian Tradition Films
results.brief_description: A trilogy of Australian stories about mateship. “Joe Wilson’s Mates”, from a story by Henry Lawson, is set in the 1890’s and is about a stranger in town who dies alone, but is given a funeral because he carries a Union Card. “The Load of Wood”, from a story by Frank Hardy, is set during the depression of the 1930’s. “The City”, is a love story set in Sydney in the 1950’s. The three stories are linked by introductory comments from John McCallum, who also narrates them. Cast includes Leonard Teale, Edmund Allison, Jock Levy, Joan Landor, Brian Vicery, Reg Lye.
